f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:39): I did some major restructuring of selectors api. It's now a lot more organised, but still have to fix up the nsresolver requirements
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:40): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Makes sense to have 'text' in the name, for consistency with every other text-drawing property and method
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:40): and also makes it clearer that it's a CSS style thing, not just a font name
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:41): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: would the value of 'textStyle' be a font name?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:42): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: it would be the css 'font' property
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:42): I think it should be called 'font'
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:42): most graphics APIs describe the way to draw text with a "font", not a "text style"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:43): whereas they do have notions like "line style" or whatever
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:43): so I do not buy the consistency argument
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:43): ok in that case please reply to vlad's e-mail :-)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:43): People seem to use CSS properties like 'font-family' far more than they use 'font', so the analogy between the canvas API and CSS doesn't really work since people aren't familiar with 'font'
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:44): right, I forgot that 'font' is a shorthand
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:44): it would be more appropriate to provide individual properties for the pieces of that shorthand, for canvas
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:44): ew
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:44): we don't do that with fillStyle
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:45): yeah, I think it should stay as font, for consistency with CSSOM property
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:45): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: but fillStyle is not a shorthand, it's just overloaded for different types
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:45): imagines very few people use the font CSSOM property, so that doesn't seem a compelling reason
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (03:47): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I will have to do some study to give a cogent reply
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:47): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, it's fairly common to see people change styles by using element.style.xxx = ...; for a whole variety of styles.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:47): although I can't say how frequently each property is used

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (03:48): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: So instead of saying "ctx.font = '10pt Arial'" when you want to set the font and aren't sure of the current canvas state, you'd have to say "ctx.fontStyle = ctx.fontVariant = ctx.fontWeight = 'normal'; ctx.fontSize = '10pt'; ctx.fontFamily = 'Arial'"? That sounds quite painful...
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:49): couldnt both .font as well as .fontFamily, .fontSize, etc. be provided like in CSSOM?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:50): the CSSOM needs to be optimised for reading
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:50): this needs to be optimised for writing

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:52): but if the author only wants to change one property, without affecting the others, then having to use the shorthand all the time would mean all properties would have to be explicitly specified, or they'd be inadvertenly reset to the defaults
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (03:53): and changing, e.g. the font-weight requires specifying both the size and family at the same time
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:53): that's the same argument as "what if you only want to change the Opacity component?"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:53): and the answer is, just implement the setter yourself
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (03:53): instead of bloating the core API :-)
